summary: Elwood P. Dowd (James Stewart) is a wealthy drunk who starts having visions of a giant rabbit named Harvey. Elwood lives with his sister Veta (Josephine Hull) and her daughter (Victoria Horne), and Veta worries that Elwood has gone insane. In the process of trying to have him committed, Veta admits that she occasionally sees Harvey herself. The director of the mental home, Dr. Chumley (Cecil Kellaway), tries to reconcile his duty to help Elwood with his own growing experiences with Harvey.

reviews.content: This is a great movie about mental illness and the injustices done to people - such as electro-shock therapy. Even if you don't get the social meaning of it, it is a sweet movie.
A truly great film that was Jimmy Stewart at his acting best, carrying on a believable running dialogue with a giant invisible rabbit-extraordinary!
James Stewart gives one of the finest performances of his career.
One of Blobbo favorites.

by 1950 this variety of screwball comedy was already way past its sell-by date. this is a rehash of far superior examples (compare this dross to some of the truly great 40's comedies like Ball of Fire).   basically an exercise in 1 dimensional "screwball by the numbers". the cynical among us might suspect that behind the warm fuzzy humanism, lies a more hard nosed Hollywood creamery designed to relentlessly milk the last sentimental dollar out of the desperate and weak minded: batty eccentric old lady cliche who prattles on - tick.  bumbling super lovable Stewart (crazy to cruel society, but in fact the guardian of some deeper truth - partly thanks to the fact he's a self indulgent white privileged alchy who doesn't have to worry about paying the rent) - tick.  standard set piece farce (i.e. people running in and out of rooms in a forlorn search of a laugh / stock zany misunderstandings and mis-identifications etc…) - tick, tick.  cumulating in a lesson in folksy wisdom / feel good dewy eyed Capra hyperglycaemia (to paper over many of the more disturbing elements of the film) tick, tick, tick…

bottom line: this feels manipulative, inauthentic, but more importantly unfunny, if you don't buy into the shallow (arguably cynical, or at worse naive) sentimental sales pitch, it really quite irritating, boring and unwatchable.

I grew up watching this movie. One of my favorites. Wonderful, funny, witty.   If you have anybody a little cookoo in your family you'll really appreciate it.  Can't wait to get a flemish rabbit one day and bane it Harvey.

I'm half-convinced that Jimmy Stewart orchestrated a multi-decade deception convincing people that he was constantly followed by an invisible, six-foot tall rabbit companion, all so he could order two martinis at a time at the bar. Shoutout to the bartender, the most supportive of Dowd's 'delusion', who gets an extra patron out of the bargain.

Harvey is like a Capra film, but with the completely untempered optimism and excessively unlikely plotlines replaced with something that feels much more human despite its fantastical nature. Mary Chase's Pultizer Prize-winning play transforms a situational comedy into a heartfelt story of friendship and love, one that prizes small character interactions and how they can kindle close emotional connections with the right amount of kindness. Characters are very ably transported from their droll, monotonous (yet oh-so-respectable) existences to an in-the-moment frame of mind, all based on interactions with a fantastical being that may or may not exist, leaving open the possibility that it was simply the spark of geniality that let such sweet moments take place. Led by a Jimmy Stewart performance that takes advantage of his endearing cadence and careful emotional control, Harvey is a triumph of generosity in an otherwise gray world. With the delusions, exasperated characters, and plot that dangles disaster in front of our protagonist, I'm surprised that nobody made a twisted, horror version of this in the '90s (except, maybe that's what Donnie Darko is). 

And here's a nice midcentury cinematic threat to keep in your back pocket: "One more peep outta you, weisenheimer, and I'll butter your necktie." Be sure to throw that one out at your next bar brawl. (4/5)
Stewart and Hull give iconic performances and while I do think this movie loses a little bit of the play's whimsy and weirdness it is probably the best adaptation we are ever likely to get.

Harvey shines the most with its comedy and its humor. James Stewart and Josephine Hull preform the humor incredibly well and the heartwarming message is still delivered well, even if it's a little cliche it's still an important message.

I normally wouldn't give such a high rating to something released in 1950, however; all this film's Oscars and Golden Globes were justified.  Barely anything exciting happens short of a Twilight Zone episode, yet the fluently of the lead character's dialogue carries the film from start to finish.  As well as it's psychological impact on the viewer; progressively justifying how the mental disorder of delusion can be a more righteous characteristic than general humanity.
They don't make comedies like these anymore.

US: One of my favorite movies is Harvey.

US_Dad: Isn't that in black and white? I don't like black and white.

US: It's not about the picture.

US_Dad: It's in black and white. I don't like black and white.

US: It's about the dialogue. 

US_Dad: I don't like too much talking.

US: What are we doing here then?

US_Dad: You were telling me about something I never want to see.
It's simply beautiful. Like a balm to my soul.

A feel good story with the dorky James Stewart playing his usual dorky self. He has a pretend 🐰 friend and he's very nice to people. Peggy Dow was a real hunny, shame she wasn't in many other films. Love the old beauts and she's right up there.
What a wonderful and delightful script.  I was chuckling throughout the movie.  I like Jimmy Stewart anyway, but he outdoes himself here in a fantastic performance.
Really cute and deeply odd.

So this is a tale of two movies. When Jimmy Stewart is on screen the movie is both very funny and touching. Jimmy lights up the screen and is obviously a superior actor to everyone else. The problem is when Jimmy isn't on screen the movie really suffers. The other actors are very wooden and not funny. Overall I enjoyed the movie and Jimmy is so good that you almost see a 6 foot bunny.
Strange unique story. Great acting by Jimmy Stewart

An average, mediocre Hollywood movie with all the trappings of something better.  The idea is good, but it is never carried out to anyone's satisfaction.   Jimmy Stewart is miscast here.  He is too amiable and too passive for the role.
Entertaining. Jimmy Stewart in a good performance.

"Harvey" is a sweet and playful comedy that, despite the thin script, ends up to be more than enjoyable. To be an "oldie" is quick and full of good quotes, and the brilliance of the two main characters (the real, and the imaginary one too) really makes the movie fly by.
As Elwood P. Dowd said I could quote him, here I will:
"In this world, you must be oh so smart, or oh so pleasant. Well, for years I was smart. I recommend pleasant."
Absolutely brilliant. Hilarious and so subtly done. Based on the award winning play by Mary Chase. It has everything including a truck load of heart.
A wonderful family friendly film that puts a smile on your face after you see this

The little older lady, Dowd's sister, is funny and very charming. The way she undoes her wedgie right before the guests arrive. So peculiar what Elwood is going through. He's known as the town weirdo. What happened in Elwood's life to make him believe he has an imaginary friend. Wow, that nurse at that Sanitarium is banging. 

So this Harvey is actually not a friend of Elwood but instead is haunting him. Damn, that Myrtle Turtle girl is desperate to find a guy.  Holy shit, that painting depicting Elwood and Harvey was pretty haunting. That rabbit doesn't look cute of goofy or funny at all. 

Great acting all around. Elwood is such a charming and good hearted person which is something not really associated with someone who thinks he has an imaginary 6 foot tall rabbit as a friend. What a turn of events once we see doors start to open by themselves and the doctor say that he's being followed. 

I can see Donnie Darko is definitely inspired by this movie. This movie is deeper than what I took from it. It seems like there's more to this movie than what's on the surface. I feel like I have to give it another watch. There's so many questions I still have. People start to see Harvey after what? Why did Harvey choose Elwood? Because he was so frequent on the booze?
Really, Only 84%?!!!  This  movie will give you back faith in humanity.  Yes, it is hokey.  And, if you pay attention, has secon-by-second humor that is absolutely delightful.
James Stewart's charm almost excuses the film's rather alarming portrayal of women, alcoholism and mental illness. It drags at times, it's not really  witty enough and overall, it's pretty creaky.
One of my all time favorite movies.

Stewart provides a wonderful performance as a man who befriends an invisible 6ft rabbit. Woven within entertaining farce lie powerful messages about the labels of insanity and tolerance. Admirably daring for its time, and entertaining still today.

"In this world, you must be oh so smart, or oh so pleasant.  Well, for years I was smart.  I recommend pleasant."  So says Elwood P. Dowd (Jimmy Stewart), a character who combines the gentle temperament of the Dalai Lama with the martini intake of Frank Sinatra.  He also seems a bit crazy, seeing as his pal is an invisible 6'3 1/2" rabbit named Harvey, and happily introduces him to everyone he meets.  While he seems harmless, his sister (Josephine Hull) wants to commit him to a sanitarium, and in a comedy of errors, gets locked up herself.  From there it's a series of screwball moments, with the hospital staff trying to track down Elwood, and him oblivious to it all.

The film is a little bit of indictment of the mental health industry, with one doctor (Lyman Sanderson) jumping to harebrained conclusions and an orderly (Jesse White) aggressively putting his hands on people.  He alludes to having had to take the corset off of Hull's character while stripping her, a fact that intrigues her daughter (Victoria Horne), in one creepy and awkward scene.  Horne at 39 was far too old for the role (Jimmy Stewart, playing her uncle, was 42), and scenes with her and White are the low points of the film.  

If it seems like just another goofball comedy in the first half, stay with it and let Elwood Dowd's benevolence sink in.  He engages everyone he meets in real conversation, cares about them, and almost always invites them over to his house for dinner or for drinks.  He does that not out of politeness, but actually wants and expects them to show up.  The character is quite endearing, and Stewart's performance is nuanced and brilliant.  In this screwball comedy, there is a real message of the importance of simple kindness, and it's delivered in a subtle way.

I don't understand why Harvey is beloved by so many. This movie doesn't make sense to me. I wanted to like it. I was excited to see it. However, I was annoyed by the plot-which only seems to be driven forward because everyone constantly interrupts each other-and the characters aren't that likeable. It also doesn't have much of a resolution. Perhaps all the hype surrounding this movie is just a figment of my imagination.
Such a light hearted charming movie and Jimmy Stewart is wonderful, as he is almost every one of this performances. It's not Citizen Kane or The Godfather, but it wonderfully fun.

Harvey is a very strong comedy, but not as great as it could have been. That third act is so serious, overly dramatic and slow that the once hilarious film suddenly stopped and lost all of its steam. Yes, the humor is terrific as the film is very funny in its great use of situational comedy and witty dialogue. The characters are memorable and very likable. James Stewart is reliably great here but this is actually Josephine Hull's show and she absolutely killed it in a very demanding, complex role and indisputably deserved her Oscar in the process.
I adore this movie and Jimmy Stewart's lovable Edward P. Dowd.

I went into Harvey with the thought that most of the movie would be held up by the charm of Jimmy Stewart. While his performance is completely endearing, I was delighted to find it was the supporting cast that delivered the bulk of the comedic moments. Stewart plays it pretty straight which is actually crucial for his character (who thinks a giant invisible rabbit is perfectly normal.) But actors like Cecil Kellaway, Charles Drake, and especially Josephine Hull are completely stymied by this rabbit. It's to the point where they can't even make up their own minds on whether it's real or not. 

The comedy in Harvey is very situational, which I enjoy, but it seemed there were not a lot of laugh-out-loud moments. I think I expected a more screwball style to the humor, but it didn't quite get there. In fact, there are some moments in Harvey that are totally serious. They are having genuine discussions about what makes someone crazy, and asking if crazy is bad if they aren't hurting anyone. It also feels like the movie answers the question of whether Harvey is real or not, and I think I would have preferred if it was left ambiguous. It wasn't a problem, just one thing that might have worked better for me if they went the other way.

The story of Harvey is not a complicated one, in fact much of it I was able to surmise from merely watching a few clips that I've seen in pop culture. You can sense the origins of the script, because the film feels exactly like a stage play. There aren't many sets or locations, and they seem to return to the same places again and again. It was in danger, at times, of feeling repetitive because so much of the movie seemed to center on finding one person or another that has disappeared. However, I never got to the point of being annoyed or bored by Harvey. It's an entertaining little film, and it's one I'd gladly watch again anytime.
A slapstick farce about a very nice man and his imaginary rabbit friend is veritably a discerning commentary on the alcoholism, loneliness, happiness and the death of good-natured humanity.
Quite funny with lovely whimsical moments and a film which says a lot about human values.
Whimsical comedy with a surprisingly modern message of acceptance and diversity. Stewart is charming as ever.
Clever and hilarious. Truly enjoyable.

Throughout the insanity of the idea of this movie, it's a wonder that I felt as charmed and heartwarmwd as I did. This feels like the plot to a horror movie, but is balanced out by the likable nature of the characters and overall execution. James Stewart went all the way and have a delightful performance. But Josephine Hall brought a sense of order and humanity to such a strange film. Also the presence of Harvey through the entire film is felt in a erie, fantastical, but still charming way.

Whimsical to the point of tooth decay, there is a darker subject left unexplored in Mary Chase's popular piece of fluff. Elwood P. Dowd is a lonely alcoholic who has compensated by inventing a 6' 4" rabbit companion and befriending every stranger he meets. The singular joke of course is that everyone else - particularly the psychiatrists and staff at the local rest home - are more bonkers than him. James Stewart is perfectly cast, and the supporting players offer the right seriousness to convince you there is more to Harvey than a rabbit-shaped hole.
I've never seen this movie until today.  Wow!  What a great movie and performance by Jimmy Stewart!

A wonderful adaptation of the Pulitzer Prize winning play largely due to superb casting and an agreeably light touch.  Stewart seems like the only actor who could play this part.  You have to accept that Elwood P. Dowd can charm people to the point that they are willing to ignore that he's a drunk who may be dangerously delusional.  You buy that when it's Stewart.  Like many studio comedies, the supporting cast is an embarrassment of riches.

Hollywood seldom makes films as charming as this anymore, Jimmy Stewart is his usual endearing self in this slightly odd comedy film.  Left me feeling warm and happy and wanting a friend like Harvey.  Worth viewing again and again over the years.
In my top 5 of all time... a masterpiece of whimsy
Harvey features James Stewart's best role and performance, and makes you feel good.
This movie overstayed its welcome, but it's ok. It has enough charm to enjoy. However, this is by no means one of the greatest movies.
Another lost flixster rating :(
And the moral of this story is: If you're dealing with addiction or insanity, run away as quick as you can!
The main takeaway of 'Harvey'? Being mentally ill is totally fine and doesn't require treatment as long as you're pleasant.
easily the best movie of all time. the acting is fabulous and the plot is so deeply intriguing.
It is an average movie that my mom has referred to my whole life but I could have went the rest of my life without seeing it.  It was nice to learn about the Irish Púca ghost though.

If you are in the mood for a fun, cheerful, and unique movie, Harvey is the one to see. Filled with crazy characters, goofy acting, and humor fit for the whole family, this movie will leave you with a smile on your face and perhaps even the slight questioning of your own sanity.

This movie is comical and very abstract. It is a very unique film that has many unexpected twists in the situation. The movie is well written and has a very good actors that portrayed the illusion of the rabbit and the story very well.

While it mostly works on the back of Stewart's presence and Hull's looney performance, Harvey suffers from an extended focus on relatively uninteresting side-characters at the expense of Stewart's Dowd. The central premise works, but the film spends way too much time having Dowd explain the already simple central conceit to other characters, resulting in long dead-patches. Additionally, the script gets bogged down in contrivances that come off as though they were written with an end point in mind and, as a result, the progression doesn't feel natural. If the game of escalating misunderstandings is done well, it appears effortless and Harvey often feels labored in its attempt to move pieces from point A to point B. It's sweet and charming, but this is a minor work. Its status as a classic doesn't seem to hold up under further scrutiny.
I forgot how funny and charming this movie is. So great seeing it on the big screen with a full audience.
One of the best comedies I've ever seen.
It had great acting and it made u actually believe that Harvey was real.Then in the end u just love Harvey and James Stewart.

What can I say about Harvey that has not already been said? It is a "sweet" film based on a Pulitzer Prize winning play, but it is a dreadfully boring movie. The play does not carry over well to the big screen as it were, so you feel like you are watching a play, which is fine. Jimmy Stewart hams his way through the hour and 30 minutes worth of running time as he pretends to actually be corresponding with a giant, invisible white rabbit where the actual giant, white rabbit in the room that no one actually sees is the fact that this movie is fun for 40 minutes and dies tragically in the last half. Josephine Hull won an Oscar for her role, a freaking Oscar. Did the Academy pull an all night booze fest and teetotal their way into this vote?

There are a few interesting notes of dialogue, but this movie is one of those James Stewart "classics" that is not very good.  Mr. Stewart had the acting range of a wet boot, and his voice is so grading that listening to him deliver his folksy, whimsical advice makes me want to punch him square in the mouth. That is coming from someone who likes a few of his films.

The movie suffers from its scenes being disconnected and from too much acting that is representative of sophomores in high school trying to work their way through a one act play. Only here the one act is Stewart and his rabbit, one that should have been pulled out of the hat early on so that the magician could take a bow. Believe me when I say that Stewart is quite the wizard as he has put the entire film industry in a trance with his hokey films.

I leave you with the line that sums up the film best:

Wilson: "Is he alone?"

Mr. Cracker the Bartender: "Well, there's two schools of thought, sir."

My school of thought is that he is not alone because multiple people would have us believe that Harvey is a real, tangible treat to encounter. I do not.
Amazing performance from Jimmy Stewart and a great story to go with it. Full review later.
Subtotal funny humor as the plot entangles and people are confused. Would you like a business card? lol
A heart warming comedy that reminds us about what matters
A pleasant, whimsical, charming, warm-hearted comedy.

This sweet movie is adorable like James Stewart's character, who charms us distributing business cards and being nice to everyone that he meets, while Josephine Hull deserved the Oscar she won for her hilarious, on-the-edge-of-hysteria performance.
Harvey contains one of James Stewart's best performances, and also boasts a fine cast and a sweet script.

It has some annoying nuances, as you would expect from a comedy of errors, but it's also very charming, enjoyable, and I loved that it didn't go where I dreaded it would.

I like that it's not just saying one thing, and there's some things to think about. At the beginning, it makes you think "no, I don't want to have anything to do with this 'crazy' man" But as the film goes by, and we meet Elwood (and Harvey) through the eyes of multiple people with different opinions and also their similar stand on the situation "we need to 'cure' him." But at the same time, we agree, "he's a sweet, sweet man."

One of my favorite things about Elwood's character is his personification of Harvey as an aid to other people's worries: "He's bigger than anything they carry" or something to that effect. Specificity aside, the quote is sensible and sentimentalist, one that I would say represents the heart of the film.

Another aspect I love about this film is Josephine Hulls' performance; she's a sweet, dignified lady whose acting style fit the movie's mood perfectly and trailblazed the appeal for the rest of the characters.

It's an interesting mix of fantasy and reality, and it did keep my attention throughout. Great movie, and it won my favor.
Hilarious and cheeky comedy.  Everyone should watch it at least once a year

This movie strikes a deep chord in me. It has something to do with childhood wonder, naiveté, and simple kindness - three qualities that can sum up James Stewart's career. This was surely the role he was born to play. Harvey reaffirms the advice the fox gives the little prince when he said, "What is most essential is invisible to the eye." It manages to achieve the same kind of message and warmth that such works as Calvin and Hobbes, Pinnochio, Toy Story, and E.T had on me as a kid. And notice that all those works are either animated or rely on special effects to accomplish its wonder/fantasy element. This movie (1951) does so entirely by means of James Stewart's lovable, bright, sunny performance as Elwood P. Dowd. I have seen the film a few times now and I swear that with each new viewing, I am able to see that big white rabbit more and more.
A charming comedy full of good performances. The issue of imaginary friends presented with ingenuity and naiveness. Recommendable.
I had a smile on my face throughout the entire film!

I understand it is supposed to be a classic, and I really love James Stewart and the premise of the film is great. Why not make this film? Unfortunately for me  Josephine Hull who plays Veta Louise Simmons in the film drives me absolutely mad. Her voice and antics are too much for me. Of course the film is dated and that has a lot to do with it. I could not manage to get through it entirely because of her.
A moving story of a man and his pooka...--Beyond sweet, beyond merely funyy, and Stewart is amazing!!

I've read a lot of reviews where people talk about the great moral tale in this movie...but I've never seen anyone reveal what that moral tale is. The only one I really got out of it was, as Elwood says, "In this world you must be oh so smart or oh so pleasant. Well, for years I was smart. I recommend pleasant." Well, I think a little bit of both is probably nearer the truth. Having said that, Jimmy Stewart is absolutely awesome as usual. And Peggy Dow provides some nice eye candy. And there are a couple of good quotes: 

"You have a lot to learn and I hope you never learn it." 

and 

"I learnt the difference between a fine oil painting, and a mechanical thing, like a photograph. The photograph shows only the reality. The painting shows not only the reality, but the dream behind it. It's our dreams, doctor, that carry us on. They separate us from the beasts." 

I'm just not sure what the overall message of this slightly odd movie is. I couldn't really get into it.

James Stewart Gives An Extraordinary Performance In This Uplifting Comedy Drama. Elwood P. Dowd (Stewart), Is A Drunk, Who Befriends An Invisible 6' 3 1/2" White Rabbit Called Harvey. This Started As A Popular Play, & It's Stewart's Performance Which Makes This Film Worth Watching, And This Is One Of The Main Reasons This Film Is Great.

An absolute delight!!  Stewart is the most polite, likeable guy you'll ever meet - if a bit eccentric. The gag runs throughout the film, and seeing how the other characters react to the little reality within this Pulitzer-winning play is timeless. Watch it with your kids or grand-kids. Better yet, borrow the neighbors' kids and watch it with them - it's that good!

A film about a guy with an imaginary friend. Works due to the performances and is a favorite because it's just such a likable film. Just like it's character Elwood P. Dowd played by the great Jimmy Stewart.
Neat and likeable oldschool comedy movie... worth a watch on a sunday afternoon.
Great performance by Jimmy Stuart. You'll swear you remember Harvey. Even tho he's invisible.
This was a good film. Makes you think a bit. You really thought  " Harvey was there " . Good stuff.

Man: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
Harvey: Everyday is a beautiful day. 
A simple, yet intricate, beautiful movie about life. I wish I could live like Harvey.
A 1950 film about a middle-aged man whose best friend is a six-foot tall invisible white rabbit... Can't get any better.
I've seen a lot of bad Harvey interpretations out there. None will compare to the masterful performance of Jimmy Stewart. I don't know of any other actor that is quite so memorable. A great film.
Calling it a comedy might lead audiences into the wrong direction, its really more of tale of friendship, a tale with personalty and charm off the charts.

By no means is this a great movie, but although very uneven and almost completely uneventful, Harvey is an endearingly pleasant movie with an amiable lead performance from Stewart and an intermittently funny script.
''...when you wear my flower you make it beautiful.''
Charming and funny, a true endearing classic.
One of the best James Stewart movies you can ever imagine. An amazing performance, and as well, one of the most worthwhile experiences for the whole family.

I expected this to be a bit better than it is. The more I see of James Stewart, the more he starts to grind on me, It might be his stupid voice, I dunno. I guess this was pretty original back in 1951 so it does deserve credit but it was a bit silly and not funny enough for me .
utterly charming and wonderfully acted.
Love this movie. Jimmy Stewart is wonderful.

Harvey, which was originally a Broadway play, has undergone little adaptation, almost to a fault. It retains the original charm, but also feels cramped in a cinemascope screen, with actors dutifully reciting rushed lines from a qucik-paced dialogue . Nauseating? Not in the least. Harvey is a poignant,  beautifully acted film. James Stewart displays a humanity uncommon in your average movie. An unforgettable gem.

Fantastic little movie.  What more can be said about James Stewart that hasn't already been said.  He could be the best to ever do it and he absolutely owned it in Harvey.  Josephine Hull was hilarious as sister Veta.  Smiles all around for this classic.

I have read that James Stewart considered Elwood P. Dowd his most personally significant role. In a career that spanned decades and included such great works at It's a Wonderful Life and Mr. Smith Goes to Washington, choosing Harvey's friend, Elwood, as his personal favorite says something about rather powerful about Mr. Stewart and Mr. Dowd.

James Stewart was a down to earth, decent man whose personal life was as honorable as the lives of George Bailey and Jefferson Smith - but he admired Elwood P. Dowd, an alcoholic dreamer with an invisible giant white rabbit as his best friend. Not what you would expect of a man who piloted B-17's and led giant raids over Germany in WWII.

Elwood's attraction for us is perhaps what attracted him so much to James Stewart. Elwood is happy with himself and his life and even more importantly, he makes others happy with their lives. That is the great magic of Elwood and Harvey: they make others happy and they bring peace and a measure of contentment to almost everyone who know them.

I have seen another version of Harvey with Art Carney and it was quite good, but lacked the sense of magic that is a benediction in this version of Harvey. In the Carney version, you can see Harvey - he is a giant white rabbit - and seeing Harvey takes much of the magic away. When you watch Jimmy Stewart, you never really know if Harvey is real or not. You know that Elwood thinks he is real and you know that Elwood's family thinks Elwood is crazy. After watching for a while, you don't really care if Harvey is real. Elwood is real and it is his belief in Harvey and what Harvey represents to him that endows him with such sweet and gentle charm. Harvey is his rejection of the harshness and materialism of the world.

Harvey is a charming, magical masterpiece of kindness and goodness that somehow never becomes maudlin. Elwood and Harvey do not feel sorry for themselves and they most certainly do not expect you to feel sorry for them either. If anything, Elwood feels sorry for the rest of the world and he does not understand how everyone can't see as clearly as he does. For in his world, we are all brothers who should love as generously and kindly as Mr. Stewart's Elwood P. Dowd.

It takes a great film (and a great performance by the always great James Stewart) to make the audience believe that a doting, possible alcoholic whose best friend is a 6'3" invisible rabbit is the only sane person in the movie.  Harvey is a simple, yet clever comedy that hasn't lost its touch with age.
I loved it as a kid, but other than the Pooka, I can't really remember much about it.
Jimmy Stewart is fantastic in this sweet, fun and heartwarming movie.  The rest of the cast are also superb, especially Josephine Hull as Elwood's sister Veta.
James Stewart - kind, humble, harmless, psychopathic...?
A terrific comedy of errors. Perhaps even better than the original play!

Fun, but a bit dated.  Alcoholism isn't as funny as it once was, our attitudes towards mental illness are a bit more sophisticated, and pleas of tolerance of oddballs aren't as fresh.  On the other hand seeing Jimmy Stewart is always a treat, and a chance to see a sweet, good-natured film should always be welcomed.

It's a great fantasy-comedy. It's a classic, but as far as classics go, it isn't that amazing.  

 Elwood P. Dowd is a pleasant mild-mannered man, who is the drunk around town (but ironically enough, he only ever takes a drink once or twice throughout the film). Elwood used to be so much more pleasant, until his mother died and he had entered an emotional phase, which 
involved him gaining an imaginary friend. The imaginary friend is very special, as he is a six foot-three (and a half, get the facts  straight) bunny named Harvey. 

 It really is a pretty charming film, a good fantasy, and still has comedy that works to this day. 

Some of it definitely would have worked better in its day, which would make it much better a few decades ago. I really rather enjoyed it though, as I do like old cinema, but I'm not sure how much it will stick out in my memory - but it really was quite enjoyable at the time. 

I don't know if I'd watch it again, but it was pretty good. 
 Some of the plot got really ridiculous at times, but it was needed in some ways. 

James Stewart is a real pleasure to watch. Some of the other actors aren't that great (like practically the rest of the whole cast, with the exception of Josephine Hull). Peggy Dow, Charles Drake and Cecil Kellaway also appear in this film. 

 If you like old cinema, or if you like James Stewart, you should give this one a watch.
This movie is delightful and whimsical. An oddball classic in a category of its own.
One of the greatest movies ever made.

I may be too much of a grinch, but this movie was just a little too zany and irritating for me.  I'm a big Jimmy Stewart fan, and his charm is perfect for this role.  But after a while saying "Let me introduce you to my friend..." twenty times gets a bit old.  I know Josephine Hull won an Oscar for this, but to me her character was like Estelle Harris from Seinfeld except stretched out in way too big doses.  There are some laughs and you can't help but feel sorry for Elwood P. Dowd, but it wasn't enough for me.

Before watching the 1950 tittle Harvey, actor James "Jimmy" Stewart was more familiar to me from his roles in Alfred Hitchcock thrillers and Anthony Mann's westerns. Thus I was initially a bit skeptical seeing one of my favorite old school actors in a comedy production where he portrays a crazed gentleman with an imaginary friend. Luckily against my preconception, Harvey turned out alright.  

Telling the story of crazed, but unbelievably pleasant, small town "nut job"  Elwood P. Dowd (Hames Stewart), Harvey is a different kind of comedy. After all, it is not everyday that you see a comedy about a man and his huge imaginary rabbit friend. Despite bit odd setting, Harvey turned out to be quite entertaining and funny. It cannot be bypassed that the film is over 60 years old and contains awfully lot back and forth messing around humor which reminded me of some Woody Allen films .. in a bad way. Thankfully much of this can be forgiven due to James Stewart's stellar performance. His act as the pleasant but very much crazed Elwood P. Dowd is convincing as it is funny and sympathetic.

Story wise there is not much to tell about Harvey, the film totally revolves around Elwood P. Dowd character and how he - through a lot of messing around and coincidences - avoids being confined to mental asylum. The film starts to be bit tedious towards the end thanks to the the extensive messing around  and the film could have easily been some 20 minutes shorter, but even as it is, the film was alright. 

In the end I still  prefer James Stewart's more serious films over his comedy ones, but Harvey was not the total catastrophy as I pictured it to be from modern perspective. And if for nothing else, Harvey proves beyond a doubt that James Stewart belongs amongst the best actors coming from Hollywood to date.
An original idea slightly annoying is invisable friend, a classic film!
This is a good fantasy movie which one can watch with their family.

Having a solid cast headed by James Stewart with support by Josephine Hull, the film follows the life of a very pleasant man, Elwood P. Dowd, who befriends everyone he meets. However, he has a major peculiarity in that his closest companion is a 6 foot 3 1/2 inch rabbit named Harvey. His loving but annoyed sister tries to get Dowd interned at the sanitarium. However, due to circumstances, things do not turn out as she planned. Along the way Dowd captivates and befriends many people with his simple charm. Rather than have her brother injected so he forgets Harvey, Hull's character realizes he needs to stay the same. With everyone in a happy and content mood, Dowd walks off again with his best friend. Stewart is wonderful in this quirky role and overall the cast is very good. I have to say I was wary of this film based on the premise but after you get past the absurdity it really is enjoyable and it reels you in.
a nice sentimental and psychological story about a man and his "imaginary" friend
A little late in seeing this movie, LOL! but I adored every moment of watching it.

If evidence was ever needed that deft writing and convincing acting can pull off even the most ludicrous of plots, Harvey is such evidence. On paper, it reads like a Dr. Suess book; middle aged man believes he has giant rabbit best friend, and over the course of 104 minutes, they indulge in some antics, meeting and inspiring people along the way. Deadpan wit is the order of the day, here. It could have so easy been lost in the shallow grandeur  of the 50s, but Mary Chase's adaption of her own play ending up being so gosh-darn charming, and Jimmy Stewart's gentle performance as a genial alcoholic is so tender, you can't help but get swept up in the punch-drunkenness of it all. Sure, it has hardly anything in terms of plot and not what you'd call a lot of witty banter either, but Harvey is an out-and-out joy to watch, a smirk-inducing, atmospheric bit of celluloid, perfectly capturing the naivety, the delight, and the mystery life has if you look hard enough
A film whereas Elwood has an imaginary friend which is a giant rabbit. As the film progresses more and more people start believing in the story of Harvey. A capturing and somewhat surprising film.
A very "pleasant" and charming picture.

This is one of the strangest films of James Stewart's career as he plays a good-natured man everyone thinks is strange because only he can see an invisible, six-foot rabbit named Harvey who is his best friend, which brings much shame to his family. They try to get him institutionalized, but his sister ends up in the mental hospital instead, and all sorts of shenanigans spring up as the doctors and his family scramble to fix these problems. Harvey is a wonderful feel-good film with a great heart and is also humorous. Now this is a great family film!
Harvey is hilarious and very emotionally rewarding.

An oversized rabbit that no one else can see except him? His sister thinks he's an idiot, his mother wants him to see a psychiatrist? Is this "Donnie Darko"? Nope, it's "Harvey", starring James Stewart in one of his favorite roles. It has the workings of a screwball comedy, also the heart of a Frank Capra film, and if you dig deeper, existentialism as well. But that may be overthinking it way too much for such an innocent and light hearted story.
Everyone should see this movie at least twice for some subtle life lessons.
In Harvey, James Stewart proves his versatility in acting. Great moral to the story.
It's was always James Stewart , the best !!
Clever, witty, charming and beautiful. A great little tale with a lot of heart. Jimmy Stewart's performance, as always, is simply perfection!

It wanted to be charming, I think, but I didn't really like Dowd...I didn't really know Dowd. Or Harvey for that matter. And is Dowd a drunk, does he have mental issues? I guess the rabbit is real, but that doesn't explain Dowd acting like he's on drugs half the time. I'd have liked to see some of those dinners he keeps inviting people to.

it was an enjoyable movie, which i think gave the idea of a six-foot rabbit to donnie darko. james stewart was well cast and fine-tuned in the lead role, a man who everyone believes is mental, because he befriends an invisible six-foot rabbit. the character emotions and changes through out the movie were invincably believable, which pretty much won it for me, and the humour the mental-hospital's doctors and nurses, and james stewart's family members serve to us on screen.
nice fairy tale that brings the test to the mind of imagination. Heart warming to the whole family that everybody will see that anything is possible, even haveing a 6 foot rabbit as a best friend!

Harvey is a wonderful movie about a nice man called Elwood (Stewart), who's rich but modest, and has an invisible friend, a huge white rabbit named Harvey.  Elwood may be a loon, but he helps people, especially with the aid of his rabbit friend. You could say this is a story for simpler times, from simpler times - as it was made in 1950 - but its message is universal, as it teaches the importance of tolerance, and the vague line between what is insane, and what is normal. The whole cast is superb, the dialogues are quick and funny, it is a joy to watch.

One of James Stewart's best movies.
James Stewart and the movie are charming.
wish i had a pooka called harvey...seldom have I seen a more likeable character than Dowd, Elwood P. And yes one would be a fool not to accept his card and go to bar for a drink and a chat... :-)
Wonderful classic movie
Have to give James Stewart credits for donning the role with so much conviction but god what a dumb story
With its play-like feel and magical connotations, this comedy with a twist offers a great amount of laughs and a few controversial topics to satisfy every cinema fan.
This was a very strange movie, but I liked it!
hm, I fell asleep. the sister really annoyed me. time to look up pooka
A brilliant work that will keep you interested. Refreshing and amazing acting.
Jinmy doing what he does best.

It's a cute old movie back when all you needed was some fun loving slapstick. Harvey reaches back into the kid inside of us and makes us love this great film version of Mary Chase's play. Jimmy Stewart just warms your heart and makes you believe in something a little outside our train of thought.
Such a lovely little movie. Jimmy Stewart is SO good in this. Wonderfully funny and heartwarming.
An instant classic, James Stewart shines like always in this picture.
james stewart plays the ultimate goody too shoes. He's good but this movie was so sugary sweet it kind of ruined it for me.

Jimmy Stewart is fantastic as Elwood P. Dowd (here...let me give you my card!), an eccentric man who loves a good drink and just happens to be best friends with an invisible 6' 3 1/2" Rabbit named Harvey.  It is a terrific little piece of lighthearted cinema that is quite funny and entertaining.  It's strong cast and funny premise holds up quite well, and the film is definitely worth a good watch.
The orginial ...the best!!
A fun film that proves its okay to be a little insane.

i loved this movie. stewart was amazing in this, as well as the rest of his family. i love the concept, and the writing was genious. it was funny, moving, and philisophical at the same time. i truly believe that there was a real harvey, but i always wondered what he symbolized.
Very imaginative film with some great dialog. It's pretty much a Stewart showcase and he entertains all the way.
Imaginary bunnies. Hard drugs? Nope..alcohol. Apparently.
An excellent comedy!  Highly recommended.
harvey is a big rabbit, this movie is cool......

This movie seemed to drag for long stretches with the storyline walking in circles. The characters at the psychiatric ward don't seem to have the brains to understand the problem and his sister (who is more loopy than Stewart) can't keep herself on topic and rambles on endlessly about nothing.  It was frustrating to see the psychiatric staff act SO unrealistic as it detracted from a good story.  Can't give it more than 3 stars out of 5 even though it was an interesting concept.

A nicely crafted, light-hearted whimsical film. A wonderful deliverance of character by the great Jimmy Stewart.

Unfortunately times have changed that has meant that some of its humour has been lost through the ages.

Absolutely beautiful film. An ode to everything good about film and about life: a lovely character, a nice disposition, and freedom of thought and mind. Just an excellent movie.
What makes it even better, apart from Stewart's just magnificent performance, is Harvey himself. How he is worked into the plot, not as a pure fantasy, but as an entity who exists, but just doesn't reveal himself to everyone. Elwood's not insane, he just sees more than other people can.
Saw it on TCM. An interesting comedy fantasy farce. Wouldn't want to see it mutiple times, but it is entertaining and causes one to think. Stewart does a very good job.
I love this movie. Who wouldn't want a giant rabbit for a friend?

Not quite as good as I had hoped, but still has plenty of positives. Jimmy Stewart is excellent as always, and his character is one of the most likable movie characters of all time. I also liked Peggy Dow, who I'd never heard of before. She's beautiful and lovable (two things that surprisingly rarely walk hand in hand) and she managed to turn a small supporting role into a noticeable one. Too bad she apparently forsake her movie career to start a family (too bad for us, but an admirable choice for her).

On the other hand, some of the characters were really annoying. Mostly the sister and that Mr. Wilson character. And the story itself could've been a bit deeper. Not by much, but just a bit to make the movie more interesting. Not that I was bored, but I wanted to "feel" the story more than I did now, instead of just following it.

Harvey is adapted from a novel of same name by Mary Chase. Last century's one of greatest actors, James Stewart plays Elwood P. Dowd, a grown up man in his early 40's, who claims of a pooka friend named 'Harvey' a 6.3ft tall Rabbit. Non-interesting it may seem to some folks, however I believe if there hadn't been humor in this movie, it would have been declared disaster. It is full of entertainment, you have fantasy, romance, as well as comedy in one pack. 

James Stewart has given one of best performances of his career since performing in Mr. Smith Goes to Washington, It's A Wonderful Life, he was nominated for Best Actor by Academy. Josephine Hull (she plays Veta Louise Simmons an elder sister of character played by James Stewart) took away Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress.

"Well, for years I was smart. I recommend pleasant."

The faith in the elemental goodness of every human being, the belief to say "every day is a beautiful day", and the honest smile that never fades-- what more can one want?

We all know how 'stinkers' we normals are in reality, and Mr Dowd has "won out over it".

So simple, yet so very special. You just cant describe some movies well enough, words flood your brain, and they fail you at the very same time!

Outstanding James Stewart and Josephine Hall! Outstanding watch!

Waiting for you Hervey, maybe we'll catch up someday, somewhere...

This is probably my favorite James Stewart movie of all time. It's so unique and original, unlike anything you will ever watch. James Stewart plays the town drunk. His sister tries sending him to a hospital, because of his imaginary friend Harvey. Harvey is a six foot tall rabbit. Harvey is a pooka (a tricky mythologic creature) It's hilarious and magical. I laughed so hard my stomach hurt.
Suspend your disbelief and enjoy one of the most original stories ever.
A man and his rabbit. The prequel to "Who Framed Roger Rabbit?"

This  is a great example of a film that proves that blue screen acting can be done. If James Stewart could give such a good performance opposite an invisible character way back then, why do people say it can't be done now? Elwood P. Dowd's good nature is too cartoony and over the top to the point of annoying tedium.

A very lightweight but sweet story with a lead character that James Stewart was just born to play. You can't help but love his tipsy, sunny disposition, even if he seems a bit mad what with his pal the pooka. My favourite part of the film was when Jimmy was philosophising outside the bar, my least favourite part of the film was everything involving Jimmy's sister, who really started to grate and was given far too much screen time.

Harvey is a feel-good film. It is about a mild-mannered, pleasant man who just happens (he says) to have an invisible friend resembling a 6-foot rabbit. James Stewart gives an excellent performance. The screenplay is well written and witty. Henry Koster did a great job directing this movie. I enjoyed watching this motion picture because of drama and fantasy. Harvey is a must see.
They just don't make movies like this anymore
This is so funny, even though its old I would recommend it
"Harvey" is a feel-good masterpiece with James Stewart playing one of the most kind-hearted characters in cinematic history.

Elwood P. Dowd: Years ago my mother used to say to me, she'd say, "In this world, Elwood, you must be" - she always called me Elwood - "In this world, Elwood, you must be oh so smart or oh so pleasant." Well, for years I was smart. I recommend pleasant. You may quote me. 

Incredible screenplay and performance from James Stewart! Highly recommended.

Favorite lines;

Mr. Martin Turner: You haven't done much walking have you Hobbs? 
Roger Hobbs: Only since I was about four years old! 

Veta Louise Simmons: Myrtle Mae, you have a lot to learn, and I hope you never learn it. 

Attractive sales lady at a department store: What can I do for you, Mr. Dowd? 
Elwood P. Dowd: What did you have in mind? 

Veta Louise Simmons: I took a course in art last winter. I learnt the difference between a fine oil painting, and a mechanical thing, like a photograph. The photograph shows only the reality. The painting shows not only the reality, but the dream behind it. It's our dreams, doctor, that carry us on. They separate us from the beasts. I wouldn't want to go on living if I thought it was all just eating, and sleeping, and taking my clothes off, I mean putting them on... 

Veta Louise Simmons: Oh good! Nobody here but people.
Far better movie about a giant rabbit than "Donnie Darko".
Sweet, innocent little film.  A bit of fluff that features some good performances.  I had to watch it so I can say I've seen every film featuring a six foot tall rabbit.
refreshing view of insanity
went oldschool with this on netflix.
Most people would call this a classic, but not me. I was very bored with this movie and couldn't get into it.
All around insane, and a bit slow at times.
"...in this world Elwood you must be oh so smart or oh so pleasant, well for years I was smart, I recommend pleasant."  A pleasant movie indeed.  Thumbs up !
A really funny and optimistic classic.
This film has been a favorite of mine, ever since I was 3. It's full of wonderful acting, and a brilliant storyline.
James Stewart is great.  I think this is the first James Stewart movie I've ever seen.  The aunt, the niece...well everyone is a pain.
A comedy classic that has all of the quirky humor and the extremely hard to hate character Elwood P. Dowd. A great movie that everyone should see.
Jimmy Stewart is brilliant as Elwood P. Dowd in this great moral tale that will leave you feeling all warm and fuzzy.
I love Jimmy Stewart!
A classic and deservedly so.

An infectiously nice/insane main character played brilliantly by James Stewart, a great skeptical reflection of the audience portrayed by Josephine Hull, and a great story make this movie one of a kind. It is funny, nice and has a wonderful moral.

A whimsical comedy starting Jimmy Stewart as Elwood P. Dowd, an extremely happy-go-lucky individual whose best friend and closest confidant happens to be a 6 foot tall imaginary rabbit named Harvey.  Elwood is part of a rich family and his sister and niece are not too fond of his imaginary friend and think Elwood is insane.  His sister is trying to Marry off his niece to a equally rich and respectable family but she fears that Elwoods little problem will harm this opportunity.  Jimmy Stewart is really great as Elwood; his demeanor is just so damn positive that its impossible not to smile while watching him on screen.  The film is full of some great moments like the scene where Elwood is taken to the psych ward by his sister.  The whole sub-story with Elwood's sister starting to imagine Harvey herself is great and its really played in a charismatic, funny way  by Josephine Hull.  Thematically it's a film about social acceptance and the idea of not judging someone just because they are different or unique when compared to the standard in society.  Well written and acted it's just a sweet, sincere film that only the 1950's seem to provide.
I adore Jimmy Stewart and most classic films, but this one was a yawner.  I can't fathom its popularity.
Amazing performance by Jimmy Stewart. Full review later.
Amazing performance by Jimmy Stewart. Full review later.
Love Jimmy Stewart...his mom, however, man was her acting tough to watch
One of the best movies i have ever seen about a imaginary bunny.
The concept of the film is original, funny, and lighthearted. Jimmy Stewart's performance is one of the film's strongest suits, and the comedy is frequently good.
Don't miss this movie, because it is sure to leave a smile on your face and warmth in your heart :-). This is a true classic in every way.

A truly classic movie! Elwood (Stewart) is a kind man, who has a big friend named Harvey. Harvey is invisible, a rabbit, and it 6- foot 3 and a half. But when Elwood starts to drive his sister Veta (Hull) crazy, she decides it would be better to send him to a mental institution. But along the way Veta has a breakdown, so she AND Elwood have to be there. This is a great film, because even though the whole plot is really silly, it maintains charm and comedy and never overdoes it. Hull gives the perfect comedy performance, while Stewart does a perfect job acting crazy. I loved this movie when I saw it, and I think you will too, if you give it a shot.
Good wholesome entertainment.
this was probably the sweetest movie i have ever seen. james stewart was great like always.
''Should any problem be solved?'' And beyond that ''Is this really a problem?'' And a simple but impressive crituque of social xenophobia

Elwood P. Dowd is a great embarrassment to his sister; he has a constant companion named Harvey, who happens to be a 6' 3" white rabbit, albeit an invisible one.  The script is very witty, but with an underlying great sadness, and one is left wondering who exactly is 'normal', and who has the better approach to life.
Love it -- quirky, charming, funny. Minor characters are just enough to keep things interesting. Once again, I will see anything with Jimmy Stewart. :)

It's whimsical, fun, terrificaly acted, well-written and more than a bit strange. I first saw this film as a child, and was very intrigued by the notion of a grown man having an imaginary friend - who may or may not be real- and who was a rabbit no less. James Stewart plays the role to perfection and Henry Costers adaptation of the play is flawless. I just plain love this film and it stands as one of my favorites.
funny,witty,sweet...great movie with great lines.

A worthwhile classic! Funny, charming, and smart with a perfect ending. James Stewart + cast are great. I love how Elwood goes about life in a pleasant manner, just letting things roll off of him. I definitely recommend it.
Very cute. I'm a James Stewart fan. Not my favorite James Stewart movie but close.
I thought it was really funny and I love James Stewart.  I recommend it.

HAVREY [1950]: By far one of the most entertaining comedy's of the 1950's; HARVEY based upon Pulitzer Winning Play of the same name by Mary Chase is one of the most sentimental, whimsical and offbeat films I have seen so far from the 1950's. And why wouldn't it be? After all the story of the play and the film is all about a kindly middle aged gentleman who's best friend is a imaginary 6 foot tall rabbit called Harvey.


THE PLOTLINE: Elwood. P. Dowd (James Stewart) is a good natured alcoholic who live a life in an upper class society. But much to his sister Veta and her Daughter ever growing shock and horror Elwood has an imaginary friend which is a 6 foot tall rabbit called Harvey. Veta wants to marry off her daughter to the right suitor but with Elwood and Harvey roaming around in their home, Veta decides to commit her Brother to the local Asylum. But in a total mix up Veta ends up being committed instead so it's up to Elwood and Harvey to save her.


The film has a lot of great performances by the main cast; Josephine Hull won an Oscar for her role as Veta in this film. But the real show stealer is James Stewart as Elwood who gives one of his greatest performances. HARVEY is one neat film that is worth checking out which is why it's got a rating of 80% from me.

Harvey is often misunderstood, and understandably so. Not because the movie itself is hard to understand, it is as plain as day that "Harvey," though invisible, is not imaginary as many presume. The misunderstanding stems from the unwillingness to believe in the supernatural. Like many of the characters in the film, viewers are unwilling to accept the obvious truth that Harvey, the six foot rabbit who befriends James Stewart, is real. Thus the movie is presumed to be about society's reaction to insanity instead what it's really about, which is insanity's reaction to reality. Also, hilarity ensues, its a fine film, they don't make em' like they used to, and so forth.
James Stewart just kills me dead. I could watch him read the phonebook for hours. However, I hated every other actor in this movie.

What is great about this film is that the audience believes that Harvey is not real at the begging of the film but by the end of film you question whether he was really real or not. I thought that Jimmy Stewart did a great job with very little to it like this was a really person yet not. Another thing I liked was the painting with Harvey and Elwood P. Dowd they had in the film.

I found it interesting how all the characters were convinced that Elwood P. Dowd was crazy at the beginning of the film but as the film progresses the characters begin to feel and sympathies for Elwood P. Dowd. Some even begin to have faith to believe in his story about Harvey.

I thought that Josephine Hull who played Veta Louise Simmons did a very good acting job. It did not come to mind how great Josephine Hull acting was for this character in the film till I heard a commentary by Jimmy Stewart on March 8th 1990. Jimmy Stewart describes how difficult it was to play a convincing character who somewhat acknowledges Harvey yet does not completely except Harvey either. My favorite scene has to be at the end when Veta Louise Simmons finds her purse after looking for it to pay the cab driver and says "HARVEY!" and her eyes open up wide. That moment is created as priceless.

What I thought was great about this film was the fact that at the end of this film it comes to be about is it more  important to be like the rest of society or to be more like yourself.
"Well, thank you Harvey! I prefer you too."

Sweet, funny movie.  Whimsical, light, innocent and feel-good.  The plot is interesting and direction solid, but as was often the case, it is Jimmy Stewart's performance that makes this movie so special.  Stewart has played some of the most likable characters in movie history, and Elwood P Dowd must be near the top of the list.  Superb performance.

Remaining cast are solid, and Peggy Dow, as Miss Kelly, is particularly beautiful.  

An absolute classic.
One of the most enjoyable movies I've ever seen, James Stewart is incredible.
One of the finest pieces of acting in cinematic history. Jimmy Stewart shows why he was and is one of the greatest screen actors ever.

Hands-down, knock-down, drag-out, my ABSOLUTE favorite movie of all time!!! A wonderful story about a man and his best friend (who happens to be a 6' 3.5'' invisible rabbit)! This heart-warming story not only has you rolling in the floor at some moments, but also has your eyes moist with the sweet realization that sometimes, being a little different brightens the days of everyone around you. DEFINATELY DEFINATELY DEFINATELY A MUST SEE!!!!!! :,D

Harvey is a wonderful movie. Jimmy Stewart is amazing as Elwood and Josephine Hull plays the neurotic older sister to a T.  Fast paced and fun, the silliness is well balanced with enough seriousness to help you understand each of the characters.
Excellent film! Excellent acting. Excellent story. Definitely a must see.

Personal Score: 10/10

No actor of the 1940s-1950s era was more enjoyable to watch than James Stewart (sorry Humphrey Bogart), and few of his movies were as much a delight to watch as Harvey.  
In Harvey, Stewart gives what I believe is his best performance as Elwood P. Dowd.  Dowd is as gentle and loving and courteous a man that one would think could possibly exist, but his kindness comes with the cost of putting up with his friend, Harvey.  Harvey is a six and a half foot rabbit, or pooka, which is invisible to almost everyone.  This is very troublesome for his niece and sister.
Veta, Elwood's sister, and Myrtle Mae, his niece, are trying to throw a party to attract the mothers of potential suitors for Myrtle Mae.  All is going as planned until, to their horror, Elwood arrives and begins introducing Harvey to the guests.  Veta loves her brother and wants the best for him, but enough is enough.  She phones a friend of hers, a judge, to help her to arrange for Elwood to stay at a mental hospital.
When they arrive, Veta begins to tell the doctor of her brother and of Harvey, but the way she says it makes her sound crazy and instead it is she who is committed!  Once the error is realized it is too late, and now everyone goes looking for Elwood.  It is then that the real magic of the film begins.
When they find Elwood, they being the two doctors from the mental hospital and the nurse, they begin to realize what kind of man Elwood is, and that, perhaps, Harvey isn't as imaginary as they thought.  It is also wonderful to watch as Elwood's influence over them begins to make them better people, and even, in more than one case, causes some to fall in love.
Harvey is a hilarious and heartwarming tale of a good man with a strange friend.  In a way, this film is a parable of a man's walk with God.  Notice who Dowd invites to dine with him, and then remember the kind of people Jesus dined with.  We find that people share their troubles with Dowd, and then he introduces them to Harvey and they forget their troubles.  It's certainly an interesting way to view the film, but I also recommend simply enjoying it plainly.  It's a wonderful tale with excellent performances and hilarious characters.  It's easily one of the best comedies ever made, and one of the better fantasies as well.
A man and his rabbit. The prequel to "Who Framed Roger Rabbit?"
They don't make films like this anymore. It's almost two hours that doesn't get dull or drag. It's funny, warm-hearted and just a pleasure to watch.

The movie Harvey, written by Mary Chase, Oscar Brodney, and Myles Connolly is a comedy about a man who says he sees a six foot rabbit named harvey. It is set in the mid 1900's and is a USA based movie. Featuring James Stewart, Josephine Hull, Peggy Dow, Charles Drake, Cecil Kellaway, William H. Lynn, and Victoria Horne.
The movie is about a man named Elwood P. Dow who claims and tells every one he meets about the six foot rabbit and/or pooka named harvey that he claims to see. But his sister Rita finely has enough of her brother introducing his friend Harvey to her friends. She finnaly decides to send him to a mental institute to have him trearted so that he will stop seeing the rabit. After much confusion  the institute accidentaley lets him go he leads him unknowingly all over town. They are looking everywhere for him but they cant seemed to figured out where he went.
One aspect of the movie that is very good in this movie is the acting. Every one stays in character at all times they never stray away. The characters in this movie are very strong and the actors make it very conviencing. For example, the character Elwood P. Dow always acts as if he sees the rabbit named Harvey, and because of that the audience always believes that the rabbit is real because he believes it. I find it to actually be the best aspect of the movie.
One bad thing about the movie was the set design. In almost every scene the background is not very convencing, it looks as if it is very fake which is the opposite effect that the writers and designers and more importantley the audience wants. For example when Elwood is in the garden the audience feels as if they are looking at a background drop and plastic flowers and plants. But there are points where the background looks real but for the most part it looks fake.
Overall I see the movie as a funny little comedy that was made very well but like everything in life has a few flaws. I believe that people will be coming back to see this movie over and over again for a long time. Despite the small unbelievablity in some of the scences and sets, it is a very enjoyable family movie and acceptable for all ages.

The movie Harvey, written by Mary Chase, Oscar Brodney, and Myles Connolly is an old comedy about a man who says he sees a six foot rabbit and/or pooka named Harvey. It was released in 1960 and is a USA made movie. Featuring James Stewart, Josephine Hull, Peggy Dow, Charles Drake, Cecil Kellaway, William H. Lynn, and Victoria Horne.
The movie is about a man named Elwood P. Dow who claims and tells everyone he meets about the six foot rabbit and/or pooka named Harvey, his best friend that he claims to see. His sister Rita finely has enough of her brother introducing his friend Harvey to her friends. She finally decides to send him to a mental institute to have him treated so that he will stop seeing the rabbit. After much confusion the institute accidentally lets him go he leads him unknowingly all over town. They are looking everywhere for him but they can't seemed to figured out where he went.
One aspect of the movie that is very good in this movie is the acting. Every actor completely fits their character and gives a great illusion of realty. The characters in this movie are very strong and the actors make it very convincing. For example, the character Elwood P. Dow always acts as if he sees the rabbit named Harvey, and because of that the audience always believes that the rabbit is real because he believes it. Elwood's sister is also a great, strong character that is wonderfully carried out throughout the whole movie.
Another good thing about the movie was the set design. In almost every scene the background is very convincing. When they are at Harvey's favorite bar "Charlie's", you can see everyone in the background reacting how you would imagine they would react if they actually saw Harvey. Also they have little things going on in the background where you can notice Harvey messing up things or doing little pranks, which "pookas" are famous for. 
Overall I see the movie as a very funny little comedy that was made very well but like everything in life has a few flaws that are overall left unnoticeable. I believe that people will be coming back to see this movie over and over again for a long time as they already have been for years. This would be a great fun, familt movie that is suitable for all ages.

The movie "Harvey" is a fantasy film set in a city, which could be anywhere, in the 1950's or 40's, since the movie was released in 1950. It is set during one night in which the main character, Elwood P. Dowd, and his "friend" Harvey are going to and from places, being dragged around by his sister.
	The movie begins where his sister and niece are having a party whilst he is drinking at a bar with his friend. They are dreading his coming, since they know his friend will ruin the party, and indeed it does when they fail to delay his coming. Later, his sister, maliciously, requests to have him committed, but after revealing the existence of Harvey, of who is invisible to everyone except for Elwood,  she is instead committed after becoming emotional about the whole situation. Elwood has been committed for a short time after this, but the doctor and nurse that had authority over them realize this, they set out to make him comfortable in order not to be sued. After this leads to a sequence to and from the sanatorium, named Chumley's rest after the owner of who becomes a major part only at the end of the movie, where Elwood is still unbeknownst to everything around him. He meets a few new characters along the way whilst the story is wrapping up.
	The character Harvey is an interesting one. Being said to be a "Pooka' which is a benign, mischievous "god" from Norse mythology, during the first few scenes you can doubt his existence but there are two tiny scenes where you can tell he is real. Of course, you never see the character aside from one of the scenes in question, but that was only for less than a minute. Everywhere else, he is invisible but has affected the ending in an important way in, with ought which, the movie could have been something different. Since he is mischievous, the ways he affects people are harmless, and the one sided conversations between Elwood, Chumley, and him can be quite interesting if not making you feel left out.
	The film is mostly conversation, but after this first fourth of the movie you never feel uninterested. It made me want to know more about what was happening, although in the beginning I never had much interest in the plot until it had made itself known, that is when his sister tries to have him committed. This is, however, a movie where if you are not paying close attention to most of everything that is being said, you will get left out in some parts, so make sure that your attention is never diverted.
This is a good film, however not perfect. It has some boring talky scenes, which where this movie is majority dialogue, has a negative effect on this movie, causing you to lose interest for even a moment, and when the important part comes into play, you are lost until you can catch up, although it's a very brief catching up time. I think this movie is perfectly fine as is, although could be improved, it's a timeless classic that should not be changed, even if you want it to.
Jimmy Stewart at his best.

An interesting and sweet perspective; maybe its lightness is naive and ignorant, but it proposes genuine advice.  It's also one of the strongest films to come out of the '50s, avoiding most of the era's pitfalls (ironically, naivety was one of them).  'Harvey,' over 60 years later, is a very pleasant movie and even as it translates across a couple generations, does so all while seeming more intuitive than shallow.

Ultimately it could even put modern cynicism into contrast: Pleasantness is timeless and always has depth.

Harvey is, without a doubt, one of the greatest masterpieces ever created. The character of Dowd is easily one of the nicest and most likable characters in all of cinema history, making it easy to root for him. Jimmy Stewart does an absolutely amazing job of acting side by side by Harvey. This is a heartwarming, mesmerizing, entertaining masterpiece that made my spirits soar. A fantastic film that I would heartily recommend to anybody. If you haven't seen this, hippity hop your way to the nearest copy you can find and watch it. (I'm sorry, I couldn't resist.)

James Stewart plays Elwood P Dowd,
A seemingly mad drunk in this relatively slow-paced screwball comedy directed by Henry Koster. The film asks us who's running the asylum and whether or not life should be lived at the pace of the hare or the tortoise. Stewart chooses hare, or in this case a rabbit but no matter who's side he's on, he's as pleasant as a monk, with the thirst of a tramp. A film as much about the philosophy of madness as a comment on class and society and all with the elephant in the room the size of a six-foot pooka. A message prescient in our fast-paced todays.
Some extravagant acting acting U can see in this movie , James Stewert was really something through the whole movie .
